Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role Of Spatial Clustering In Group Organization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Dr. Daniela Triadan, Melissa Burham will investigate the social and spatial organization of ancient Maya cities through time. Many scholars have focused on evidence from the center of Maya cities, households and settlement patterns to understand social and political organization. However, in complex, urbanized societies, social groups such as neighborhoods, districts and local communities, develop at levels between the household, the city, and the state. These were important spheres of social reproduction and negotiation both in the past and present, and help to unify different groups of people into cohesive social, economic and political systems. Archaeology is well placed to study how diverse groups formed in the past, and how they articulated with the larger society through time. Burham's project contributes to a growing body of research on intermediate-level groups by focusing on the interactions that fostered local identities, which may have included ritual practices, co-residence, and the management of communal resources, like water. By looking at developments over a time span of almost 2000 years, this project investigates the nature of early urbanization and explores how early complexity shaped later society. Furthermore, by studying the role of water management in social integration, this project carries implications for understanding sustainability and resource management in urban landscapes, both past and present. Burham's work provides methodological and theoretical approaches for studying different levels of community organization, and hence offers new insights into the development of urbanism and social complexity in ancient societies.

Burham's research is part of the Ceibal-Petexbatun Archaeological Project, which consists of an international team of collaborators directed by Dr. Takeshi Inomata and Dr. Daniela Triadan. Ceibal, located in Guatemala, had an extensive occupation from the Middle Preclassic through the Terminal Classic periods (ca. 1000 BC-AD 900), and appears to have had a well-structured city plan. It is therefore an ideal case to study the spatial and social organization of people living in outlying areas through time. Burham's project focuses on minor temple groups, which are located at regular intervals in outlying residential areas. Many researchers have suggested minor temples were important integrative hubs in lowland Maya settlements. Building on these perspectives, this project investigates minor ceremonial groups, how the people living near them related to the temples and to each other, and how the practices and social relations undertaken at the temples influenced the larger sociopolitical order. Minor temples were likely the physical and ideological centers of local communities at Ceibal. Although they may have been discrete social units, the formation of these groups was crucial to shaping and sustaining the larger society, especially as populations increased and social hierarchies became more pronounced. Focusing on evidence from five minor temple complexes and the residential structures surrounding them, this project assesses the degree and nature of social integration of local communities by examining whether they were: 1) arranged into spatially-distinct zones and organized in association with at least one temple; 2) had a source of water within each zone that supported the local community population; and 3) had a distinct pattern of material culture within each zone, resulting from similar access to or preferences for certain goods. An examination of multiple lines of evidence over a large time span provides a basis to better understand the formation of intermediate social groups, and for exploring how community organization may have changed throughout Ceibal's history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In complex urbanized societies, social groups such as neighborhoods, districts, and local communities develop at levels between the household, city, and state. These are important spheres of social reproduction and negotiation, and help unify different segments of the population into larger social, economic, and political systems. Our research on outlying minor temple complexes at Ceibal, Guatemala sheds light on “intermediate-level” organization in ancient Maya settlements during the Preclassic (ca. 1000 BC-AD 200) and Classic (ca. AD 200-950) periods, and offers insights into urbanization and social complexity in ancient societies more broadly.

At Ceibal, minor temple groups (pyramid-plaza complexes smaller in scale than the monumental center) are located at regular intervals around the site core. We hypothesized that minor temples were the physical and ideological centers of different local communities. To test this assertion, and to understand the formation and degree of integration of potential communities, our project focused on three lines of inquiry: 1) whether populations were organized into discrete residential zones around temples; 2) if there was evidence of local water sources, which would have been important locations for daily interactions among community members; and 3) if material culture varied across different minor temple groups. 

Between 2012 and 2017, we systematically excavated five minor temples and nearby houses. Furthermore, we performed several different geospatial analyses using Geographic Information Systems programs (ArcGIS) to assess residential clustering around, visibility of, and accessibility to minor temples. The results revealed multiple zones of high settlement density across the Ceibal area, each of which is associated with at least one ceremonial complex. Each temple underwent multiple modifications, and nearby residential areas were occupied at the same time as the temples. Minor temple groups were not established simultaneously. Rather, different groups of people constructed their own temples at different times as they settled permanently in new areas. Participation in communal temple ceremonies and collective efforts to maintain the complexes may have helped foster local group identities. Temples were so important to local community formation that many groups carefully buried their temple before abandoning Ceibal at the end of the Terminal Preclassic, around AD 200-300.

Several of the residential zones also contained a reservoir large enough to support the local population. However, the analysis of pollen in soils collected from the reservoirs revealed that the features only held water seasonally. Nevertheless, the reservoirs would have been important sources of water for local populations. The results also suggest the areas around the reservoirs were deforested, and that maize was cultivated nearby. In contrast to temple ceremonies, these features may have been important locations for more routine interactions among community members.

Statistical comparisons of the pottery assemblages suggests that there was little variation in consumption patterns between communities during the Late Preclassic (ca. 350-75 BC). However, consumption patterns between groups varied more greatly during the Terminal Preclassic (ca. 75 BC-AD 200) and Classic periods. This pattern may be tied to increasing social and economic differentiation through time.

Our research reveals that Ceibal was socially and spatially organized into discrete intermediate-level groups. The members of local communities were integrated through ritual practices, co-residence, sharing resources, and collectively maintaining shared facilities, such as temples and reservoirs. On a broader scale, the findings suggest that populations living in outlying areas of Maya cities were relatively autonomous: they managed their own local resources and agricultural production, organized their own building programs, and carried out many of their own rituals.

Our research provides important insights about how people organize themselves in urbanizing contexts when there is little-to-no oversight by a central authority. Although urbanization is often understood as an explosive process, the data from Ceibal suggest that in some cases, incipient urban growth occurs in a piecemeal, organic fashion. By studying the role of water management in social integration, this project carries implications for understanding sustainability and resource management in urban landscapes, both past and present.

Several Guatemalan archaeology students were trained in field and laboratory methods over the course of this project. Students learned to oversee their own excavations, to carefully document the findings, and to critically assess data in order to answer anthropological questions. The results have been presented at both academic and non-academic conferences, including the Society for American Archaeology annual meetings (2017, 2018, and 2019), the Maya at the Lago Meeting (2017), the Symposium of Archaeological Investigations in Guatemala (2017), and a public defense of the Co-PI’s dissertation (2018). The Co-PI also wrote a post for A Day of Archaeology, and plans to present at local retirement communities and schools in Tucson. Field reports were submitted to the Institute of Anthropology and History (IDAEH) of Guatemala, and detailed descriptions of the data are included in the Co-PI’s dissertation. A book chapter for an edited volume is currently in press, and additional articles are underway.
